Portal is a game that feels like a Half-Life 2 mod. That being said, it is a REALLY, REALLY, REALLY, GOOD HALF-LIFE 2 MOD. Seriously i'm debating whether or not this game is better than Half-Life 2 because it is just near perfection. The villain is near perfect. It revolutionized puzzle games forever. The puzzles always make you think hard. Not gonna lie, this might be the best game Valve has ever made, that or Half-Life 2. Its just everything and it wastes no time if you know what you're doing. Portal is a masterpiece and an easy 10/10.
I love this game, Though, It is very short. But it is Valve's first puzzle game and it is a fun 4-5 hours and is a good price.
The best single player game I ever played, totally recommend!
fun game they should make a sequel to this

Truly one of the best games ever made, with an even better sequel! The puzzles are both simple enough to know what you need to do, but challenging enough in execution that you feel accomplished once completing them,

Memorable boss fight, memorable character and dialogue. A must-play for every gamer!

P.S. Stay for the song at the end, you're gonna love it! :D

https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=2814156770
„Ö§„Ö§„Ö§You wake up in a tiny chamber with transparent walls, greeted by a friendly robotic voice. The furniture in your room amounts to a bed, a toilet, and a wee coffee table with a radio on it; the voice informs you that you've been briefly detained in a so-called [i]'relaxation vault',[/i] and this sentence alone sets the mood of the game immediately ‚Äì the mood for which Portal will be remembered and appreciated for many years to come.

„Ö§„Ö§„Ö§You are a test subject, a guinea pig ‚Äì and you can't even recall your own name; the only way out is forward, through testing chambers of increasing difficulty, following the guidance of a robot who encourages you and announces your inevitable demise in the same impersonal, but somehow sardonic cadence. Nothing is alive here ‚Äì and the frosted-glass observation rooms stare at you with their dead fluorescent eyes, revealing no discernible human shape behind them, cold and completely indifferent. Only acid pits and High Energy Pellets ‚Äì which, as the robot readily informs you, [i]'can and have caused permanent disabilities such as vaporisation'[/i] ‚Äì accompany you on this perilous journey.

„Ö§„Ö§„Ö§For the reasons mentioned above, Portal is an exciting game to play now, and it will remain an exciting game to play for as long as civilisation and electricity are a thing. It is fairly straightforward and short ‚Äì I did everything there was to do in the game several times over and clocked 15 hours ‚Äì but it is fundamental, in the same sense as a wheel or a button are fundamental; its key principles and discoveries are implemented in countless other games to outstanding effect. That alone is a good enough excuse to schedule a quiet Friday evening to complete Portal in one sitting. It deserves the full extent of your attention, and it gives so much in return.
https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=2814161811
„Ö§„Ö§„Ö§When you get through all 19 chambers and eventually finish the game, you will unlock Challenges, which is where Portal shines the brightest, [strike]frying your brain[/strike]. You're invited to complete several chapters once again, but this time with additional requirements: Least Portals, Least Time and Least Steps. This approach ‚Äì allowing you to complete the same test chambers while looking at them from a different angle ‚Äì is nothing short of brilliant. I had so much fun with the first two tasks, but the steps mechanic in Portal is somewhat broken due to inertia: if you press W for a fraction of a second too long, you'll take another useless step, and that's annoying. Also, when objects collide with you, it counts as a step, which makes no sense. Overall, completing all three Challenges, while undoubtedly fun, is nigh impossible without guides, unless you're exceptionally intelligent ‚Äì in which case you should probably be doing rocket science, not playing videogames.

„Ö§„Ö§„Ö§Challenges are not the only thing to keep you busy; Advanced mode adds several hurdles to familiar levels, and while you're not limited in the number of portals you place and the amount of time you spend, solving these still takes so much brainpower that, if converted to energy, would be enough to keep the Eiffel Tower all lit up for a solid month or two.

[table]
[tr]
	[td]üèÜ [b]ACHIEVEMENTS[/b][/td]
[/tr]
[tr]
	[td]‚öîÔ∏è CHALLENGE[/td]
	[td]üìÖ MISSABLE?[/td]
	[td]ü©∫ BROKEN?[/td]
        [td]‚è± 100% PLAYTIME[/td]
[/tr]
[tr]
	[td]üü®üü®üü®üü®üü®‚¨úÔ∏è‚¨úÔ∏è[/td]
	[td]‚úîÔ∏è[/td]
	[td]‚úñÔ∏è[/td]
	[td]~13 hours[/td]
[/tr]
[/table]
[quote]Most achievements have something to do with either Challenges or Advanced chambers, but you will also be tasked with completing the entire game once again while finding all radios and detaching all cameras from the walls in a single playthrough. The presence of exhaustive guides facilitates the whole ordeal by an order of magnitude, but if you're the stubborn type and don't need anyone's help, better make sure you've got your wits about you.[/quote]
„Ö§„Ö§„Ö§Have you ever played a videogame with developer commentary? If yes, you already know how awesome it feels, if not ‚Äì you're in for a treat. Playing Portal and being able to peek behind the scenes is not only like seeing Santa Claus when you're six, but also getting to sit on his lap, take a picture and make a wish. I never truly realised how deep and multi-layered the process of creating a videogame is, and how many issues playtesting may reveal in a product that looks perfect on the surface. For those who've been enjoying computer games since childhood, it seems baffling that some folks fail to understand the key concepts which are second nature to some and utterly alien for others ‚Äì for instance, simply looking up when controlling a character in first person. Portal devs will reveal this and many other secrets to you, and it's insightful enough to warrant a third playthrough.
https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=2814156069
„Ö§„Ö§„Ö§üìåSo, do I recommend Portal? I actually can't recommend it enough. GLaDOS ‚Äì the impersonal, murderous robot ‚Äì and her unnerving jokes made the initial journey extremely fun, if a little stressful, and the inventive gameplay additions kept me coming back for more. Ignoring Portal, assuming you've never played it before, is akin to robbing yourself of a good time. Why would you do that?
[h3][b]After completing all Testing Chambers, visit [url=https://store.steampowered.com/curator/41449676/]our Enrichment Centre[/url] for more high-quality reviews. Rest assured ‚Äì we play newer games, too.[/b][/h3]
